1111.content:
The street was a hive of activity. People rushed by in both directions, hurried by their constant affairs, and most were so absorbed in their own lives that they could scarcely keep from colliding into each other (especially when one was less than half their height!). It was a sea of individuals, the space in-between a contradiction to the isolation of each man and woman.

Buddy, however, had no time for philosophy, he had a job to do, which was more than most of his fellows he knew could boast, and his job was his life. Past steaming grates leading into the sewers and stinking tail exhausts of cars that seemed to be positioned to emit right into his sensitive nose; Around broken patches of asphalt and stubborn on comers in the flood of humanity who would sooner correct their route than a boulder in a stream; Over piles of refuse that sometimes built around the overflowing trash containers like the base of an expanding pyramid and puddles of black, semi-congealed goo in the potholes that was less than half water and well on its way to evolving into a higher life form. Each curb, every bump was a challenge and Buddy noticed them all for he had the most important job in the world, as far as he was concerned, leading a human safely through the chaos all around them.

The towering black skinned, gray furred human behind him was known to other humans as “Dr. Mathias,” but Buddy had no need of titles, he was his human and that was all that mattered. The golden retriever that helped the good doctor get to his elementary school where Buddy would rest under his desk for most of the day was aware that his master was an important human; he had a seat on the board of education and if he was rather busy most of the time, at least Buddy was always by his side and ready to lend a friendly ear or belly to rub during those times he became stressed during work.

Yes, Buddy couldn’t imagine being anywhere else than beside the tall, dark man in the sunglasses. His harness and his cape stitched with the words, “Please do not pet me, I’m working” might as well have been made of gold for the way that he carried them and had been carrying them since puppy hood when Dr. Mathias got Buddy from “The Seeing Eye.” He’d spent more than half of his short, canine life in the company of his human and the fact that his best years were behind him meant as much to Buddy as the plastic bags that floated by in the cool Autumn breeze.

Buddy stopped at the curb as he had been taught and had done a thousand times since. His tail stiffened at the sight of the massive angular metal carts that humans rolled around in passing by; they were a threat, always a threat to the safety of his charge. For while Buddy knew that Dr. Mathias was vastly more intelligent, and larger than he was, he needed Buddy to guide him. There was nothing like the feeling being able to help such a great being in such a tangible way; it filled the aging guide dog with pride every time he stepped off the curb. Dr. Mathias came to a halt beside him and briefly patted Buddy’s head while they waited.

After a few moments, Dr. Mathias cocked his head this way and that, listening for traffic as Buddy knew. He said, “Forward.”

Now, at this moment, the critical moment, Buddy was in charge and had an important decision to make, Go or stay. “Selective disobedience” humans call it, but really all it was was letting the dog decide. However, as was ground into Buddy long ago by his mentors, this was a life and death decision at every crossing. Buddy never forgot, but the years wear on one’s sense of caution and even more heavily in the form of conditioning. The Golden had walked his route virtually every day for… as long as he could remember. Day in and day out, it was the same. Though he was as blind to the mysteriously colored traffic lights as Dr. Mathias, Buddy looked ahead and saw the cars lined up neatly to the right and judged it safe. He stepped forward.

A car came sailing lazily in from the left as it arched through the intersection. So slow was it moving that Buddy thought that surely it would realize there was an elderly man and dog in the street and stop. But it didn’t. The golden retriever, so very proud just a few moments ago in his very important job froze, his mind refusing to process quickly enough. His paws started to grind forward, but it was as if they locked in molasses, he wasn’t nearly as swift as he had been a few years ago. The car, however, didn’t wait for Buddy and soon a glowing headlight shined down on him, and filled up the world, like the eye of death drawing him into itself; that bumper was just the right height to catch him in the chest and break him to pieces like an egg dashed on concrete.

Buddy felt a push from behind and then he was flying. Funny, he would have thought getting hit by a car would hurt more, but then perhaps he had died instantly and was simply floating away…

The guide dog landed hard on the asphalt and the noise of the world which had fallen strangely silent returned in a flood, except with a few additions. There was the screech of tires for one, a woman was screaming, the humans were talking excitedly… and there were groans coming from behind. Buddy turned and found his cherished master lying face down on the road behind him, hands outstretched towards him. …He’d pushed Buddy out of the way at the last second. The good doctor’s legs lay twisted, the gray pants of his expensive suit marked with the hideous black of tire treads. Dr. Mathias lay gasping and groaning, clenching his hands again and again; Buddy smelled his master’s blood.

The entire world seemed flipped on its head. Things were not supposed to be like this. Dr. Mathias had placed his life into Buddy’s hands… it was what he lived for. Now… now not only had Buddy failed his human in the most terrible way imaginable… but his human had sacrificed himself to save him. It was a strange and horrible reversal of fate. He should be the one to gladly give his life, not this…

Buddy crawled forward like a puppy and settled his golden furred head near his owner’s. Gently he extended his tongue and licked some of the grit away from Dr. Matias’s face. A bony hand rose and grasped him gently behind the head, rubbing the inside of his right ear the way he had done for more than half a decade. Now the driver of the errant car was running over, cell phone in hand. The young human moved as if to touch his human, but Buddy showed his teeth and growled menacingly for the first time in his life; no more harm would come to his master from this man. Buddy started to rise, but the hand on his head grew tight.

"No… Buddy.” Dr. Mathias croaked, a thin stream of blood and saliva leaked out the side of his mouth. “Down…. Stay…” Buddy settled down, but the hand relaxed before his hackles could even lower. Buddy licked his human’s, his companion’s, face again, but there was no gentle response, no cracked smile this time. Pleadingly, Buddy looked to the young man, but he had backed off, still talking urgently into his cell phone. All around, humans watched as the one man Buddy cared for in all the world silently passed on, an invisible wall about ten feet in radius from the body formed; many humans were on their phones, possibly calling for help, but Buddy wasn’t so sure, one was pointing and taking a picture. ‘Why won’t they help?’ Buddy wondered, ‘Doesn’t anyone care?’

Desperately Buddy licked Dr. Mathias unceasingly, all about the head and face as a brooding bitch would trying to lick life into a still pup. The Golden’s mouth was dry by the time the ambulance arrived.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -

The kennels of the Seeing Eye were cramped compared to the spacious apartment he was used to; it was also cold, damp and stank of the nearby puppies as they learned their toilet training. But above all of the discomforts he had suffered since being parted with the cooling corpse of his previous owner, it was lonely. Buddy curled up with his hind feet under his chin, as if he might squeeze himself into nothing if he tried hard enough for surely his life as he knew had passed with the generous man who had saved his life.

Buddy was not a young dog, but he looked even older now for lack of eating. Buddy had never been a particularly thin dog, enjoying a good meal as much as any other canine and his master being generous with his scraps, but now his belly tucked up frightfully under his chest and his ribs showed; patches of his beautiful coat were starting to fall out. He tried to sleep, but every time he closed his eyes he saw the aged, wrinkled face of Dr. Matthias, eyes glazed, bloody drool leaking out the side of his mouth. Buddy lifted his head and howled until he was hoarse.

Buddy wasn’t the only older dog at “The Seeing Eye” in fact; he was now “retired” a couple years before most; though usually retirees remain with their families as pets. The pups were nothing but pests, all legs and motion, jumping and playing, all the while disgracing themselves with their lack of discipline… The older dogs knew failure when the smelled it. It was fortunate then that the waiting list for retired service dogs was years long, highly trained dogs always being greatly desirable. Buddy found himself in a strange new car speeding away from the enclosed yards and kennels of “The Seeing Eye” before long.

Turning away from the rear window, Buddy settled down in the seat to avoid the bumpy, unfamiliar motion of the car; Dr. Mathias hadn’t drove for obvious reasons and Buddy now thought that it was fortunate the way that his belly was churning now. Besides the aging guide dog sat a small girl in a cute little dress, on the far seat was a very tall girl with black hair and black lipstick and black gloves with the fingers cut out… she wasn’t very cute at all, Buddy decided. In front, a be-speckled, balding man whose fringe of hair was a lighter shade of Buddy’s own coat, very handsome, the dog thought, drove and beside him a plump human female reclined, a face mask over her eyes and snoring quietly; her smock smelled of butter and dough. Fairly strange humans all, their skin like bleached bone compared to his former master’s and all of them were much younger. The human girl-child intrigued him, Buddy had curiously little time with children for all his owner worked in an elementary school, mostly he had sat in his master’s office with outside breaks during class time.

Cautiously, she , with her rosey pink cheeks spotted with freckles, reached out and touched his tail. Buddy swished it and she giggled, retracting her hands to her mouth. The tall girl-child rolled her eyes and twirled her finger on the plastic rectangle he held, a soft crashing noise that sounded like construction work issued from behind her limp black locks of hair. Buddy ignored it and continued to entertain the small girl-child with his long bushy tail as the tall buildings eventually gave way to smaller houses and then to forest…

Eventually the trees gave way to wide rolling hills covered with vast farms and still the car moved onwards. This family must have traveled a long way to get him. Buddy was no great thinker, but his long experience told him that these people must have really wanted him. Eventually, the little car, with a pause to fill up the gas tank, came to a new human city, though not so nearly as vast and tall and the canyons of gray sculpted stone, glass and steel he was used to. Just outside of the heart of the city, the car turned off the freeway and entered into a quieter area. Here the houses were more widely spaced, though many were identical to Buddy's eyes. Wide spaces of green grass lay in front of every home and trees were abundant; Buddy had never seen such a sight, 'So much space!' he thought.

By the time the car pulled into the driveway of a wide three storied house, Buddy was wagging his tail for the first time since the terrible accident and his failure. The little girl next to him leaned over and grasped his neck. She whispered, "Welcome home!"

11111.content:
The balding man attached a rope to Buddy’s neck—so different from the harness—and brought the dog inside. The door opened and Buddy was met with a shock, the door opened into a little room rather than the great space he had been expecting from the sight of the exterior. Buddy had never seen stairs inside of a human home before either, he smelled furniture polish overlaying old wood. A picture of the man holding his leash, albeit with a full coat of golden fur and smaller versions of the two girls behind him sat on a small end table beside the steps. Still befuddled by the strange little room, Buddy hardly noticed when the man unhooked him. Buddy looked up.

The man had a soft, round face, small nose, even for a human, and thick square glasses. That golden hair, only a few shades lighter than his own, marched around the sides of his head, leaving his crown barren save for a sad attempt at a comb over.

“Peter! Won’t you come get this big ol’ bag of dog food?” called the voice of the man’s apparent mate. She came to the front door while the man turned around and left, waddling a bit. The big female was actually a little more than plump, in fact, she was bordering on rotund. Taller and more than half as wide again as her mate, the female dwarfed him. She had a long face, though the effect was mostly spoiled by the size of her cheeks which appeared full like a squirrel’s and the thickness of her neck which almost suggested that she had to swallow several softballs or a small melon. She carried nothing from the car but her minuscule purse leaving her husband and children to collect the various supplies given by “The Seeing Eye.” Buddy’s tail wagged when the tall girl all in black grabbed his old dog bed from the back, it was one of the few items left from his previous life as he thought of it.

Once the rest of the family was coming, the plump woman pushed open a door and all of Buddy’s misconceptions of smallness vanished in an instant. There was a spacious living room with rich leather furniture arranged around a massive flat picture box that humans loved so much. Real rich leather, the tantalizing aroma was almost like sugar sprinkled on the air currents, but Buddy was able to resist temptation; he was a disciplined working dog… or at least he was. He still didn’t know what role he would play in this household, certainly all of the humans seemed perfectly able to see and guide themselves. It seemed that he was destined to become nothing but a spoiled pet without a job—and therefore without a life—though he couldn’t expect anything more. Who would want to rely on an aged guide dog who had led his charge right into the jaws of death?

Buddy sagged, but the small, rosy cheeked girl child ran up to him and threw her arms around him once again, kissing him on his forehead; he managed a half hearted lick in return. Then the human girl did a most peculiar thing. Pulling back her toes off the ground, she slide forward and seemed to glide across the wooden surface of the floor.

“What did I say about skating in the house, Lauren? Take those wheels out right now!” commanded the plump woman from the other side of the kitchen counter. Already there were succulent smells wafting from that side of the room.

The tall, pale girl walked right past where Buddy was sitting, dropping his cherished dog bed on the floor without stopping and virtually ran upstairs without a word. Buddy heard a door slam shortly followed by the same chaotic din he had heard issuing from beneath her hair.

The husband, apparently called “Peter” came in, staggering under a mighty bag of kibble. He threw it down beside the stairs and stretched his back, groaning a little. Buddy looked up and cocked his head quizzically. “Oh don’t mind her, she’s always like that.” He said and cupped Buddy under the chin with his palm. Buddy might have nuzzled back, but he couldn’t find the heart to do so. The man took a folded piece of paper out of his jacket pocket and read it carefully. He leaned to the right and peered out across the living room to the kitchen to make sure no one was watching and then he smiled to himself. “A real guide dog, well, let’s see what you can do.” He muttered to himself.

“Down.” He said. Buddy laid down with almost no conscious input.

“Up.” Buddy stood up.

Peter checked his paper again. “Ready.” Buddy walked over to his right side and turned forward. Now was when he was supposed to be fitted with his harness to begin his very important, and now miserably failed job. The man looked down with a silly grin on his face, but Buddy felt only disappointment since it was obvious that they weren’t going anywhere.

“Forward.”

They stepped forward together into the living room where the smaller girl-child, Lauren that was it, was placing the plastic tabs over the holes where the wheels had been in the soles of her little pink shoes. Buddy didn’t like humoring the man for his own amusement, but the commands were too well ingrained in him to even think about disobeying them. “Hault.” Said the man in the glasses before the kitchen counter.

The plump woman already had her sleeves rolled up and was wrist deep in flour. So near the floor, Buddy couldn’t see the dishes, but he smelled fresh dough, tomato paste, beef, cheese, herbs and vegetables. “See what a good boy Buddy is?” said the husband

Buddy was surprised when the large female slammed her chunky fists into the counter, rolling something and then striking again. “I still think we should have gotten one from a breeder. My cousin knows this wonderful woman who has the most beautiful French Bulldogs.”

The be speckled man grimaced visibly. “Honey, you know I don’t care for little dogs. I need a dog we can play with.”

The plump mate to the man next to him looked over the counter down at Buddy where he had already sat down. “Then you should have adopted a puppy. Look at all that white on his muzzle.” She gestured dismissively down at Buddy, “And didn’t they say he’s going blind? He cost almost a grand and now there will be more vet bills.”

“He’s just losing some of the sight in his left eye, Sweetheart. The Seeing Eye said it’s unlikely he’ll go completely blind.” This was news to Buddy. Blind? In one eye? He hadn’t noticed anything different with his vision, but then those tests with the flashing lights at the kennels came back to him; they way the technicians had muttered and mentioned Dr. Mathias. Is that why he hadn’t seen the car coming?

“Hmph…” said the wide female and punched her dough even more vigorously. Peter wisely decided to make a hasty departure. Peter put the big bag of dog food away in the pantry and stowed a couple of his old toys and a couple new ones away in a basket in the living room, Buddy following all the time. He picked up Buddy’s bed and walked up stairs. It was a longer climb that Buddy was used to, Dr. Mathias had always taken the elevator and his hip hurt a little by the time he reached to top.

Upstairs, there was a long hallway flanked by many doors. Peter walked all the way to the end and though Buddy instinctually wanted to sniff at the bottom gap of each door, he followed dutifully at his side, the way that a true guide dog should, just in case. Buddy wondered half-hopefully if Peter had any medication to fetch, or possibly a cane. He opened to door to a darkly lit room sporting a wide double bed with a black comforter. The man put Buddy’s bed at the base of it on the floor and then took a seat in at the nearby desk and computer. Buddy stood by for a long while, waiting for Peter to move, but when he didn’t and seemed to slide into concentration the way Dr. Mathias had over his papers, Buddy pushed his way between his legs to lie down under the desk… or at least he tried. Peter’s leg wouldn’t budge to admit him. Buddy looked morosely up at Peter. “Go on, Buddy. Sniff around, make yourself at home.”

To Buddy, home was being at the side of his charge, home was being useful and dependable. He laid down under Peter’s seat. A few moments later, however, Peter rose and Buddy was forced to get out of the way of the chair legs. “Go on Buddy,” said Peter, pushing him out the door with open palms. “Don’t be a pest.” The door shut and Buddy was left outside. ‘A pest…?’ he thought and he ears lowered.

Buddy sniffed at the bottom of some of the doors, instinct prevailing in his idleness. ‘Is this what pets do?’ he wondered, ‘wander around aimlessly sniffing until they find something interesting enough to hold their minds for half a minute?’ He had never considered himself to be a “pet,” he was an assistant dog, the best of the best. More than half of his comrades were thrown out during selection at the Seeing Eye when he was but four months old. He was supposed to be better than this… And he was supposed to keep his owner from dying also. Below the door behind which came the music like a busy construction yard came the scent of make-up, incense and cigarettes. It was the first room he had smelled those filthy tar sticks in and he wondered if she were doing something she oughtn’t. Buddy scratched the door almost experimentally. He immediately heard fumbling on the other side and the closing of a window. “I’m trying to listen to The Wake! God!” The music suddenly became much louder and of course, Buddy had no words to say to her so he left.

Somehow going down the stairs hurt worse that going up and Buddy took his time with it. There was a time when he would have rushed down stairs like these almost at the same speed as falling (and more often than not he did), but it seemed that age was taking more than just his sight. Downstairs, Buddy had something warm, soft and buttery jammed into his mouth before he even knew what was happening. His first instinct was to gag, but the warm buttery lump tasted so good, it would have been a crime, so he swallowed. “See, Mom? He likes it.” Said Lauren, wide smile almost cracking her face in half.

“Well let him have as much as he wants, we have to finish off this batch of dough, it’s going to go bad.” Said the plump female from the kitchen.

The Little girl grabbed a platter of fresh, straight-from-the-oven, pastries, what were they called? Ah croissants. His owner had liked to put a strip of bacon and a little butter inside as a breakfast snack. Lauren settled in front of wide, world filling screen before them. Right now, there was a yellow rectangle with eyes and brown pants dancing with a dopey pink star in trucks. Strange things humans find entertaining. Lauren offered him another croissant and though all of them were slightly burned, it was still like a rich buttery heaven exploding on his tongue. Hardly chewing, Buddy found within himself an appetite of a much younger dog, not that the pastries required much chewing, they practically dissolved in the mouth. Giggling, Lauren passed him one after another and soon the dozen or so that had rested on the platter had utterly vanished. She hugged him again around the shoulders while Buddy licked his chops. “Mama, Buddy’s so skinny, his ribs are poking.”
The plump female laughed, “Not for long if I keep burning these croissants. Here give him these too.” Buddy wagged his tail.

111111.content:
Croissants may be tasty, but they aren’t very filling as Buddy found. When the family sat down for dinner, the pale daughter practically having to be dragged down from her room by Peter, Buddy saw an elaborate set up on the great dining room table. Far more elaborate than Dr. Mathias’s single dish recipes for himself, here there was a bowl of corn and a bowl of green beans. There was a big bowl of mashed potatoes and a dish containing something fried and smelling of fish. But the main course was a great platter of browned pastries that smelled of meat, cheese and potato swimming in butter and sautéed onions. Peter’s plump mate sidled over and placed a kiss on his cheek. “Homemade pirogues for Buddy’s new home.”

“I knew you cared about him, Angel.” Said Peter taking a seat at the head of the table.

She crosser her arms as much as her more than ample bosom allowed and said, “I care about you, honey…” She looked down at the golden haired dog lying content and full of croissants in the living room, “Maybe he’ll grow on me.”

She served everyone a plate and the pale girl with the long black haired made a face. “How many times do I have to tell you, I’m vegetarian.”

“Yeah yeah, and vegan last week, and the week before that you ate only fish and the week before that, you wouldn’t eat anything white.” Said the mother.

“I can’t eat this.”

“You can and you will or you’ll go to bed hungry.” Said Peter. “As long as you live under this roof, you’re going to be a carnivore like the rest of us.”

The pale child pushed her plate away and let out a high pitched shriek, “You both don’t understand me at all!” She stormed off past him and Buddy moved out of the way of an ill placed kick. Pup.

Peter’s mate sighed and picked up the pale child’s plate, but Lauren grabbed her sleeve as she moved to the sink. “Mommy, let Buddy have it, I think he’ll like it.”

The plump female shrugged and put the plate down on the ground. With the odors coming down off the table, Buddy’s paws practically moved of their own accord. Despite having put away more than two dozen croissants, he easily found room for the little meat pastries, the fried fish, the potatoes and every drop of gravy. He was finished before the cutlery began to clink on the table above. Lying down, belly distended, Buddy relished in the sensation of fullness. The purely animal satisfaction of having one’s gut filled was a pleasing and previously forgotten experience. ‘Well…’ he thought, ‘perhaps there are some perks to being a lazy, do-nothing pet.’ He belched and crawled under the table where greasy little fingers would often hand him a tidbit that kept his mouth and mind occupied.

That night Buddy curled into his dog bed while the heavyset female snored in the great bed behind him. His food stuffed belly weighed heavily on him, however, and he slept more soundly that he had since the terrible day he had let his master down.

1111112.content:
The living room, floor of polished wood, scuffed in places where Lauren habitually forgets to removes the little wheels from her shoes, it’s massive flat picture box a monolithic alter to entertainment and commercialism around which all the rest of the furniture in the room is arranged, save an ancient grandfather clock which didn’t tick and a mantle above a bricked-up fireplace filled with pictures of the family, even a new one containing a golden haired dog.

*Blink*

Now the living room was an incoherent mass of brown with black smudges in front of him vaguely where the leather sofas were an instant earlier. Buddy squinted with his left eye, but matter how hard he crunched the lens nor how he cocked his head, his bad eye no longer gave him anything but a senseless mass of color; he couldn’t even distinguish floor from wall from ceiling, all lines and borders were obliterated and out of focus. He reopened his right eye and rose unsteadily to his four paws. The rapid deterioration of the vision in his left eye over the last month still left him with frequent vertigo; often the only way to get around was to keep his left eye shut, but that was tiresome and he often forgot. At least he wasn’t tripping over his paws anymore…

For all his troubles with his sight however, Buddy couldn’t complain about his family. Peter and Lauren were just as ready to love and accept him into their fold as his old owner. Their hugs and constant pets were reassuring and Lauren’s youthful energy, so different from Dr. Mathias’, was infectious so that when she occasionally was able to provoke him into a game of chase, he felt like a spry pup again.

The wife, who Buddy had since learned was called Marian, never warmed up to Buddy in the same way. The diligent cook of the family who tolerated Buddy’s presence but never went out of the way to cuddle or comfort him was oddly the human around whom Buddy spent most of his time. Both the sweet girl-child and her taller, spiteful sibling disappeared in the mornings with their father and did not return until late in the afternoon most days. Often Buddy had to find a warm spot near the stove to keep the chill out of his bones, but not so near that he was in Marian’s way for while she did not aim kicks at the golden dog, she did not care to alter the step of her thick and somewhat clumsy feet to his presence either. Of the pale child who wore nothing but black… Buddy hardly spared a thought and just kept out of her way; she hardly spent anytime down stairs anyways.

Buddy yawned and stretched, while the first few days had been like a nice vacation, his constant idleness was hard to cope with sometimes and he often resorted to patrols of the house to stave off boredom. He stalked off from the kitchen where Marian was preparing a sandwich for herself (the second today, really it was no mystery why the woman was as big as her husband and offspring combined) his long golden coat freshly restored with his regained appetite swishing about him. His luscious coat wasn’t the only thing new about him, he had regained all the weight he had lost and then some on his rich diet. Peter saw to it that he had hearty portions of kibble twice a day, but always during dinner, Lauren would sneak him not only tidbits from the table, but often over large quantities of leftovers after the rest of the family had left the table. At first, Buddy was only too happy to take this childish show of affection, especially since Peter had bought him an inferior and rather tasteless variety of dry dog food, but now that his belly had softened and his chest thickened, Buddy thought he would have to start turning away some of the girl’s offerings. “Perhaps tomorrow…” Pondered the sleek golden dog as he padded his way slowly up the long set of stairs.

He arrived in Lauren’s room , pushing the door open with his nose and sniffed a bit. Fabric softener was still strong since the last wash of the bedding with an underlay of juvenile feminine sweat from when Lauren would come home and throw herself into bed after soccer practice. There was some dust, more than downstairs since Marian did not particularly care to climb the stairs save to go to bed and also the stale odor of an old punch stain near the bed. His nose told Buddy most everything he needed to know about the room as he explored, though he still swiveled his head around, giving his right eye a chance to take in the mundane visuals. In this room, however, there was almost no need for his good eye as the overriding color of the interior was pink. Pink walls, pink bed, pink pillows and stuffed animals, even the little television was pink and lots of pens with pink fluffy bits attached to the ends littered the little desk; surprising, the floor was not pink, but the same beige as the rest of the house. Buddy gave the best post and experimental lick where he smelled Lauren’s hand grease and then settled down on the rug for his second nap of the day.

11111121.content:
Though cars often passed in front of the great house during the day, Peter’s SUV that he used to pick up and drop the girls off was distinctive and the golden dog knew immediately when they started to pull into the drive. This was a good thing since it took Buddy a while to get down the stairs. He had to go at it at an angle, letting his rear legs keep up with the fore, otherwise the twisting and the angle of descent pained him in both shoulders and hip; it was hard getting old.

Strange, when he came at last to the landing on the first floor, his nose crossed a path of Marian’s scent heading out the door. It was a lingering trace only, which meant that Marian had left something after Buddy had gone to sleep. It didn’t weigh on his mind more than a curiosity, however, he was far more concerned with the coming of Peter and Lauren. The young girl burst through the front door first, bringing a veritable explosion of youthful energy.

“It’s Friday!” She squealed and threw her arms around Buddy. The golden folded his right leg and dropped onto his side, raising a rear leg so Lauren could rub his stomach; no longer gaunt, but now pleasantly plump and healthy pink where the fur was scant. Peter walked in carrying his briefcase and coat in one arm. He left his hat and coat on the nearby rack and found time to give Buddy a quick rub with his foot once he had taken his shoes off. The pale girl in black who wore her usual scowl mixed with an expression of extreme boredom trudged her way into the anteroom and threw her backpack around the post of the stairs where Buddy knew that Peter would have to take it off and deliver it to her room later.

She leaned against the wall, arms crossed, “Dad, I need some money, I’m going out with Althaia tonight.” Her tone, for once, was reasonably civil; just like every other time she wanted something from one or both of her parents.

“No dear,” said Peter calmly, “Were staying home. Your mother said she has a surprise for us and a special dinner.”

“Oh… My… God…” said the girl, dropped her tones like dead lead weights, “I’m not going to be part of your suburban, materialistic family, Peter.”

Peter grew red in the face at the sound of his name from the child, “You will not talk to me like that in MY house, Jillian Turner.”

“My name is Jinx!” screamed the girl so that her flat black hair swung wildly about her.

“Go to your room this instant and don’t come down until your mother comes home!”

She left in a huff and without another word; altogether it wasn’t the loudest or most intense outburst Buddy had seen and he had only been living there for a few weeks. ‘Peter should think of something else to do with her.’ Buddy thought, ’I think she likes it up there in her room.’ But it was hard to dwell, when one’s stomach was being rubbed so generously that one’s leg starts to kick.

Buddy thought things were going to settle down, that is until Marian arrived. She came in huffing slightly from the incline up the driveway and instantly, Buddy’s nerves were on alert: he smelled another dog. A lot of information was contained in a dog’s unique scent, and before Buddy even rose, he knew that there was something off about this dog. One’s scent is affected by one’s diet and this dog had an oily flair and also it was a little sickly like it didn’t get out often. It was male, but he was neutered, like Buddy himself, so the smell didn’t inflame his natural territorialness. Marian came in and announced, “Surprise!” as she put down the oddest looking dog Buddy had ever seen.

His coat was all over black except for a few tufts of white hair on his chest and his ears were enourmos and stood up, rounded like those on a rat. He had no nose to speak of, almost like a human and he hissed when he breathed. But far and away his most noticeable trait was his protruding gut, bald like a hill at the top and exposing his pink skin and such a size that it looked like the small dog had swallowed a cantelope. He easily the fattest dog he had ever seen, there was no space at all behind his forepaws when he sat, which he did immediately after being placed on the ground. Quite round, he was wider at the middle than at either his hips or shoulders and Buddy wondered if those little legs could lift the dog at all. He cocked his head and his initial confusion at the sight disrupted his usual greeting sniffs; the little dog did not seem inclined to move over and greet Buddy either, though for probably much different reasons.

Peter came down the stairs and haulted in a similar mannar as Buddy, “…Wow, that a…”

“French Bulldog! His name is Lewís. Isn’t he adorable?” Marian reached down and grabbed the preening black dog and squeezed him around the middle, not unlike a stuffed toy; however, in that moment, Buddy felt a hot spur of jealousy that this fat blob of a dog had earned Marian’s affection in a way that he had so far been unable.

“Yes, but when… where…?” Peter’s words were failing him in view of his mate’s enthusiasm and Buddy took comfort in the fact that his master did not seem automatically seduced by the pudge dog.

Marian set Lewís down on the floor again and this time the little dog managed to todder off a few steps so as to be out of arm’s reach before planting his relatively enormous rear. Buddy walked over to the black dog as Marian finally took stock of her husband’s expression and said, “I just brought him over from Julian’s to visit. Don’t you like him?”

Peter struggled to escape from her trap. “Well he’s nice, but I’m just wondering why…” Buddy greeted the bulldog with a quick sniff (stronger evidence of a diet over-rich in fat now and little if any exercise), while Peter spoke quickly and more than a little frantically, waving his arms sometimes at Marian’s looks.

The black dog turned his rump around the other way and said in their own tongue. “Well excuse me! I think you’ve got me at the disadvantage here.” Lewís warned him off with his little, and much worn, teeth. Buddy back off a step, he thought he knew the source of the bulldog’s agitation, it must be difficult when one was not only so much smaller but also so fat that one could not get away very easily from a potential aggressor. He felt pity for Lewís.

“I’m sorry, I was just sniffing. Do you want to come over and smell me first?” A calm disposition was key in a guide dog and Buddy prided himself on it; he’d had nothing but friends back in the city.

“Thanks, but it’s rather too much trouble, how about we just talk; You have a name Fido?” asked Lewís.

Again, this dog struck him as a very strange sort, why would he bother with the silly titles humans gave their dogs? Most canines he knew simply identified each other by sight. “My family calls me Buddy.” Vaguely he was aware of Marian saying, “Well, you have your dog and I can have mine.”

“Hmm…” said the little round black dog. He shuffled his hindquarters on the floor and moved his front feet over the swell of his belly; he sat on his right thigh, left splayed out awkwardly to accommodate his girth. Buddy didn’t think his posture looked comfortable at all. “Well, I suppose I’m glad to meet you… Buddy.” He said his human given name with distaste, but Buddy couldn’t care, it was a meaningless title at its root, not who he was.

Buddy laid down facing the blobish dog to meet better on eye level. The adults were beginning to raise their voices and Lauren retreated upstairs. There was silence, which wasn’t a very accurate description since dog spoke mostly in body language, and Buddy’s curiosity finally overwhelmed him. “I’m very sorry that your family has made you so fat; have you tried eating less?”

The bulldog’s rear leg waggled in the air and it took a moment for Buddy to realize that he was trying to scratch his ear. “Oh I would never do such a thing. My owner likes me as you see me, in fact, I try extra hard at meals to get down everything they give me.”

Now Buddy was really sent for a loop, and also more than a little disgusted, “You let yourself get that fat?”

“Naturally, Humans love fat dogs” said the ridiculously obese bulldog, “I’m the favorite because, I put aside such notions as ‘fitness’ as the most important virtues.”

“They do?” asked Buddy
Lewís nodded, “Humans want something soft and squishy to hug at the end of the day.”

“But don’t you miss getting around?”

In response the French Bulldog rose and waddled a few steps, great belly swaying like a cow’s. “I manage, besides, running’s overrated anyways.”

Buddy was about to inquire more about this strange concept, but then Marian shouted, “…Well you can just make your own dinner then too!” She stomped over and picked up the bulging black dog who could hardly move a step away from her wrath before she was on him and stormed out the door. Peter hung his head in his palms and Buddy walked over to lick his face, but Peter pushed him away. That night, when Lauren had finished giving him his secret snack, he nipped on the hem of her skirt until she gave him more.

Max had first been walking through the park when he noticed it, the sudden grating feeling in his hips. He felt it for a a few paces before it stopped; but a few paces later, the feeling returned. Max endured the pain until he got home before he flopped on the ground. Max's owner was a single lady of about 50, who was a fitness buff and as in shape as possible. But Mable was a sweet lady, who cared dearly for Max and pretty much let him have his way.

         Mable free-fed Max, whom she noticed only ate what he wanted and was otherwise a healthy weight. She had gotten Max from a man whom she now knew was a puppy miller; but she hadn't known that when she had gotten him. Nevertheless, he was a sweet, kind dog who had never taken advantage of her kindness.

         When Mable called to Max to serve him dinner, she heard the familiar clatter of nails on hardwood, but followed by an audible "pop." Mable had never heard this before. Had Max hurt himself or was that just a result of his lying down. But she heard the noise again, so she decided to call the vet to discern the cause of this noise. It was a ghastly noise which made Mable cringe for her dog.

         When Max indeed had risen, he felt the familiar pain in his hips as he walked toward his food bowl. Feeling to tired to stand up to eat, he lay down and began eating. The food felt good and seemed to cause the pain to subside considerably. Mable had never seen her dog lie down to eat before, so she called the vet and scheduled an appointment for the next day.


         Max was given couple of treats to give him a shot for an x-ray, which the vet promptly took. Having deliberated for a few minutes, the vet returned and told Mable: â€¦

11121.content:
When the vet told Mable this, Mable started crying. Why had this happened to her dog? She quickly dried her eyes before the doctor offered her a Kleenex and continued, "Because Max has hip dysplasia, you need to exercise him very lightly and feed him very lightly." Mable didn't hear the last part, however, because she was heartbroken that her baby had lost everything dear to him. "We could always put him to sleep," the doctor offered, which only solicited a glare.

         The doctor authorized giving Max two Advil tablets a day, one with breakfast and the other with dinner. The Advil would only ease the pain slightly, however, enough just to make it tolerable. On their way home from the vet, Mable and Max had a tradition of driving through a fast food restaurant and getting Max a hamburger. And this time was no exception.


         Because Max's hips hurt when he walked, Max found that many of his previously enjoyable activities became too painful to do. Max would lie down restlessly until he discovered something he could do with his time and energy: go to his food bowl. At first, a whole bowl would last Max throughout the day; but as he became accustomed to the size of the bowl, it would only take him three-quarters of a day; and finally half a day. Eventually, Max could eat his whole bowl of dog food with gusto at breakfast and dinner.

         Before Max had discovered his hip dysplasia, he had been a thin, rather well-muscled dog with his ribs nearly-visible; but in the course of a month, the time it took Max to accustom himself to his new bowl, he had lost that defined muscle tone, and had gained a thicker coating of fat over his ribs. He wasn't overweight by a normal German Shepherd's standards, but he was approaching being slightly overweight.

         When Max had first finished his whole bowl of food in one sitting, Mable had pitied him and refilled his bowl, which Max had at first sniffed at, but then left alone. But Max ate it in the morning, and Mable filled his bowl again, knowing that Max would regulate himself as he saw fit. At first, Max had eaten a bite out of the bowl and went to lie down for a nap; but the smell of food kept having Max return to it and eat it.

         Eventually, Max found that there was no food left; but Max was fine with that because he felt too full to eat more. But when Max had slept off his food, Mable returned soon after and refilled his bowl while she put Max outside to relieve himself. When Mable noticed that her dog's food bowl was empty, however, sheâ€¦

When the food was gone by the next morning, however, Mable was slightly concerned until she saw that Max had only just eaten the food; so she refilled his bowl and got ready for work. When she came to give Max a goodbye pat, she noticed that his bowl was empty again, "You must be hungry, huh, Maxie?"

When Mable got home, she found Max asleep on the ground by his empty food bowl. Max perked up when he heard his mistress's footsteps. 11131.content:
The family entered the car park of the animal shleter on the outskirts of Bingham, their hometown. The father, Sam, was a thin man of average height. He worked in an office, but wanted to spend more time at hime with his family, so he decided to set up his own home business one month ago. The mother, Katie, a petite, but quite plump woman, was talking to her children in the back. She loved her family more than anything in the world, and felt that there was room for one more: More specifically, a dog. In the back seat, their two children, eight year old Jack and six year old Sophie, were both well behaved and happy children, who wanted to have a dog to play with.

They got out of the car, and walked into the shelter.

"Hello," said Katie, who was holding the door open for her kids as they walked in, "we're looking to adopt a pet dog."

"That's fine," replied the slightly bored looking assistant, who looked up from the paperwork on her desk. "Follow me," and she held open the door behind her desk, to the animal cages, and lead them through. She gestured to the cage closest to the door, and Jack and Sophie peered through the glass hatch into the cage.

Inside the cage, was a tired looking white Labrador, called Ben, according to the sign on the cage. His fur was short, and looked slightly dirty, but he looked at incredibly peaceful as he lay curled in the corner. Suddenly, the ears perked up, and his eyes opened, and the dog stood up, reveling something about himself.

He was deplorably scrawny and thin. His stomach and waist curved up sharply behind his exposed ribs There was not an ounce of fat on him. Ben then walked up to the glass window, peering out at the two human children before him. 'Please take me with you,' he implored the two children, but all they could here was a low whine. It still did the job.

"Aww," they said together, and looked up to their Mum. "Can we get Ben please Mummy," asked Sophie.

"We'll see sweetie," she replied, and turned to the assistant. "Can we please have a better look at this dog?" she asked her, and the assistant opened the hatch, letting th Labrador out. He jumped out of the cage onto the floor with a small clatter, as his paws hit the tiles.

"I'll leave you alone for a while," said the assistant, who went back into the office. Ben sat on his skinny haunches, tail wagging, looking expectantly at the family. Sam ran a hand down Ben's side, and the dog instantly relaxed, nuzzling up against the mans leg. The two children started to stroke at his sides.

"He's really skinny Mummy," remarked Jack.

"I know, but we can sort that out," replied Katie, who bent down to cup the Lab's muzzle. "You're such a sweet little boy, aren't you?" she said in a baby-voice to the dog, and Ben replied by giving her cheek a small lick.

"I think I know who we're taking, don't you kids?" said Sam, and his children nodded. "Miss!" he called out to the assistant.



About ten minutes later, Ben was theirs! They were riding back to the family's house in the car, and Ben was remarkably calm, as he lay sprawled accross the two children in the back seat, who were petting him half to death. As Ben lay there, he was thinking of how good his new life was going to be.

They pulled into the drive of their house. It was a normal sized, 3 bedroom yellow-brick house, with a large garden. They walked into the house, and removed their shoes, still stroking their new dog. Ben was looking around at his new home. There was carpet, which eased the strain on his tired paws, used to harsh concrete. And heating, meaning he would no longer be shivering as the nights colsed in. There was plush furniture and the entire house looked incredibly homely. It was luxurious, it was comfortable, and Ben loved it already.

"Come on Ben," said Katie, walking into a room off of the hallway, the Kitchen. There, she put down a rather large amount of food for him in a shiny, silver bowl. Ben padded towards it over the linoleum floor, gave it a small sniff, and looked up at her, curiously.

"Go on Ben, dig in. We're going to make you healthy again!" and with that, he dug in with gusto into his first proper meal in over a year, as the shelter never had enough food to feed him enough. As he ate, Be could feel his stomach growing fuller and tighter, not used tot his level of filling, but the Labrador cleaned the bowl of it's meaty goodness. After eating his fill, he lay down on his side, allowing his new master to stroke him. He relaxed in the bliss of having his belly eased and massaged, and dozed into a nap, happy for the first time in months.
11131.title: Ben

111312.content:
Ben was hesitant and reticent around his new family at first, whom he wanted to get to know better before he made premature judgments about him. He had been naïve when he had immediately trusted his previous owner. Such thoughts made him shudder hungrily. His previous owner and even the animal "shelter" had failed miserably to feed Ben properly. These factors, combined with his breed's appreciation of food and its availability thanks to his new mistress had led Ben to use food as a crutch to cope with his struggles.

It had been a few days since Ben had been adopted. Ben quickly learned that Katie was a complete pushover towards him whenever she cooked or ate, so she tended to give him food from her plate. She also fed him as much dog-food as he requested; he merely had to whine for a couple of minutes and flip his bowl; and his master or mistress would fill his not small bowl to its brim.

Ben had to start slowly at first; but even now, he noted an ever-increasing capacity in his stomach to hold food. Ben also got little exercise. His house had its own yard, Katie and Sam were too lazy and busy respectively to walk him and the children were too young to walk him outside by themselves. Thus, coupled with Ben's last few months of sedentary activity in the shelter, he was really quite happy to lie around and have his family rub his body all over. Katie still fussed over him that he was too thin and vowed to change that.

That promise came to a head at the end of that week. On Fridays, it was the family's custom to get a meal out. That night, because Jack said that he was feeling ill, Sam went out and got Wendy's. Ben overheard his own name mentioned in the order, although he had no idea what a, "Triple Cheeseburger with Bacon and a Side of Large Fries," was, it sounded curious. Ben patiently waited for Sam to return, a wait which seemed eternal.

Finally, Sam returned with a greasy bag of food which smelled ethereal to Ben. As he unloaded the bag, Sam unwrapped a large, greasy thing which seemed to be he pinnacle of the ethereal smell. After he had given everyone else his food, Sam picked up the greasy delight and placed it in Ben's bowl, where Ben made quick work of it and the other greasy strings which tasted good, but not as good as the pinnacle of other-worldly delights.

This trend would set a trend that would continue every Friday, to Ben's delight.
111312.title: Later that week

1113122.content:
Six months passed. Ben grew not only more trusting and tranquil, but also more massive. Ben had gone from a messy pile of practically skin-and-bones, to having a well-contoured, hour-glass-shaped body, to having increasing less defined ribs, to being almost rectangular in those six months. This thicker fat made lying on his side more comfortable for Ben as well as lying down generally. Ben's fourth "birthday" also passed, giving Ben's family an excuse to give him a small pepperoni pizza of his own and a generous slice of cheesecake.

A few days after his birthday, on a day when even the kids were home, after his breakfast, which had increased from three-quarters of a bowl to three bowls of food on average, Katie awoke Ben from his dozing with his leash, a sign Ben took for a walk. His gullibility was rewarded, however, with a trip to the Vet. Ben, being a socialite animal, enjoyed the Vet.

As Ben approached the car, and after Katie had unlocked and opened it, Ben attempted to jump in. He jumped with a huff and got his front legs in the car; but when Ben tried to get his back legs in, he found that he couldn't. Katie, being slightly concerned but thinking nothing of this event, pushed Ben into the car. When Ben had mounted in it previously, it had been from a lower side-door, not from the way-back.

The drive was uneventful; and when they arrived, Ben hopped down with his usual grace a little more slowly than he would have liked. The smell of animals was overwhelming and exhilarating for Ben, who would have loved to meet all of the animals; but this place also brought up the sad memories of his days at the Shelter. As he walked into the reception area, he noticed many dogs; but one in particular caught his eye.

It was a massive German Shepherd. He stood two or three inches taller than Ben; but aside from being taller, he was substantially heavier. While Ben's abdomen made a small fold of fat outward when he sat, this dog's made large deposits bulging away from his body, which hung to the floor and rested upon it. When Katie had finished, she walked over towards the great German Shepherd and began to talk to his owner; but not before giving him a brief moment of attention, calling this dog Luke.

When the older woman asked how Ben was doing, Katie replied that he was fine. After hearing Ben's name, the regal German Shepherd spoke first, "So, this woman is your mistress?" He inquired, cocking his head slightly towards Katie. When Ben wagged his tail, Luke continued, "Good, sorry that I haven't given you my usual honors, but my knees aren't feeling too good today. It's hurts a bit to stand."

Ben understood sympathetically. And responded, "So how long have you been with your mistress?" Luke wagged his tail and chuckled, "I've been with Lady Helen for six happy years. She's taken exemplar care of me and fed me well. I take it that your mistress feeds you and cares for you well?" Ben nodded, so Luke continued. "Excellent…" but he trailed off as he smelled something. Then, Ben knew what he smelled: treats, specifically hot dogs. There was no one else in the reception area, so Helen handed Luke a whole hot dog and handed Ben one for good measure. Katie chuckled, "You love to spoil your dog, don'f you, Mom?" Helen chuckled and nodded and fed both dogs another hot dog for good measure. When Luke pleaded, Helen emptied her pockets, which made Luke tilt his head in surprise.

Suddenly, a nurse appeared and called Luke's name; and Helen stood. And slowly, Luke pulled his front legs under him; and after scrambling for a few seconds, he managed to do the same with his hindquarters and slowly pushed himself off the ground, panting from the exertion. Ben noticed none of these things except the grandeur of Luke's standing physique. Even when he stood, Luke's flanks and abdomen bulged outward with fat. As Luke waddled slowly away, Ben watched Luke's graceful and serene body sway.

Thus, he told this woman that her dog was healthy and had her go on her way. "Ben, do you wanna go to Granny Helen's house and play with Luke?" Katie cooed. Ben didn't exactly feel like playing, he was too old and dignified for that; but he did remember the woman who had fed him hot dogs at the vet's office and wagged his tail. Ben had no idea that his family was going on vacation, but the moment Susan left, he missed them. Luckily, Luke and Helen were pleasant company.

Luke had at first been skeptical when Ben arrived because he thought that he would be given less food than he liked; but in reality, Helen gave food more freely than she would otherwise have, Luke noted, at his first meal with Ben. Both dogs were given a large plate of leftovers each, as well as free-ranged kibble. On the morning of the second day, however, Ben heard Luke scratching and whining for Helen from the kitchen. Helen was already in the kitchen; and when Ben walked in sleepily, Luke met him with a challenge, "Hey, Ben, I bet you can't eat as much as I can." Ben was intrigued but sleepy.

Suddenly, Helen walked over, picked up Luke's bowl, filled it, and set it down in front of him; and she did the same with Ben's. Ben ate and ate; and when he had finished, he looked up and heard Luke whine to Helen for more food. Ben walked over and sat expectantly. Overcome with the dogs' entreatment, she filled their bowls again. This time, to Luke's disdain, she filled Ben's first. This happened until Ben finished his fourth bowl, which had made him mildly uncomfortably full. Luke, however, appeared to be unaffected. After half of his fifth bowl, Ben slowly backed away; and Luke devoured it quickly. Luke continued like this until his sixth bowl, after which he was forced to admit that he was finished. And although Helen filled both of their bowls again, neither dog touched his food.

However, while the two dogs took a nap to digest such a meal, they smelled and heard the sizzling of a juice that came only from a sausage. Luke seemed to have noticed this too because he blearily lifted his head and body up and wandered slowly to the kitchen, following Ben, who sat expectantly at the stove. There, Helen did not disappoint either him or Luke. Muriel cooked more sausages than a single woman, or person would eat in a single meal.

With their breakfasts digested somewhat, there was room for the sausages which Helen seemed to enjoy giving to her dogs. Helen even poured the sausage grease over the kibble the dogs had left untouched that morning, which helped the dogs devour another bowl each. Soon they went back to napping.

When he awoke, Luke was still asleep next to him. Muriel was sitting on her couch watching television. Ben felt sated, but not full. Ben rolled over as quietly as a lab can, but Luke still noticed and awoke. A piercing gurgling came from Luke's stomach, so both dogs deemed that it was time to eat again. Each dog found a nice pile of assorted meats in his bowl, which each wolfed down quickly and started scratching at the floor around their bowls. Helen obliged the two dogs and filled their bowls once.

However, when the dogs whined again, Helen went to her fridge instead of the food-bag. When she closed the freezer came a delightful scent: peanut-butter and ground-beef balls. The dogs both ate ball after ball until each and every ball was gone. Suddenly, Ben realized that he needed to go outside; so Helen let him out. Luke plodded out down the stairs after him. "H-hey, w-wait up," Luke huffed after going down just three steps, lying down after doing his business.

However, when it was time to go back inside, Ben was hit with his first sense that something was off with Luke. If going down the stairs was tiring, going up the stairs would be very difficult at best. And it was for Luke. First, Luke managed to heave his front paws up onto the first step, then feel with his hind leg for the first step while he probed for the second step. It was an excruciating process, but Luke finally managed to reach the top of the stairs.

Luke turned his head slowly to look at Ben. "Yeah, just tired. I guess I'm starting to get a bit old, huh?" the obese German Shepherd panted as he struggled to control his breath. Ben decided not to press the issue any more that day.

Luke looked at Ben with a look of pure disbelief and disgust, "What are you saying? Is this about earlier? I told you; I'm fine. I appreciate your concern, however." Ben nodded, a little more appeased; and happily ate all the food he was provided.

Although his stomach didn't bulge outward when he stood, he knew that he was closer to that landmark. Luke could now fit another bowl of food, and Ben another one and a half. However, shortly before Katie came, something else happened with Luke.

As Luke tried to stand up on the kitchen's tile floor, he scrambled up onto his front legs; but when he tried to heave his hind legs under him, he couldn't, which left him stuck until he finally managed to get his legs under himself and heave himself up. Ben decided that he wanted to be like Luke. After saying enthusiastic greetings to his masters and mistresses, he sauntered over to his food bowl and started nosing it. Sam, who was sitting at the kitchen table looking over stock prices, heard the gentle scraping of Ben's bowl acrops the floor; so he filled Sam's bowl with kibble. A few minutes later, Sam heard the Sam noise and reluctantly filled Ben's bowl again. At the third time that he heard the bowl, Sam tried to ignore the scraping; but he couldn't.

Fortunately for Ben, Katie walked into the kitchen, noticed Ben's actions, and filled his bowl again. Sam was concerned, "Katie, do you think maybe that Ben looks a little…thick-skinned?" Sam was a soft-spoken, but assertive man, who had few demands. But Katie was stubborn and saw no issue with Ben's health and size; so she replied, "No, why do you say that?" Sam realized that he was trapped. If he responded, his response would trigger an argument; but if he didn't, Katie would demand to know what he thought until he told her what he had been thinking. However, he tactfully responded, "I was just wondering. Perhaps he's just a big dog." Katie nodded, a bit disconcerted; and absent-mindedly filled Ben's bowl again.

Ben had his bowl filled a few more times before he went off to take his morning nap. When he awoke, however, he recognized the smell of those peanut-butter, ground-beef balls which Helen had made. Ben stood and wandered into the kitchen. "Hey boy," Katie cooed in her irritating fashion, "Do you want something to eat?" At the word, "eat," Ben began to wag his tail. Seeing Ben's reaction, Katie handed him a "Satin Ball." Katie had made a large batch of these treats and fed them very liberally to Ben.

A week passed, one day, however, while Ben was in his mid-morning nap, he heard Sam's voice call his name. Groggily, Ben rose and trotted over. Ben was holding Sam's leash, "Wanna go to Helen's house to see Luke, Ben?" Ben wagged his tail happily. He would love to see Luke again. Although he hadn't gained much weight, he had some news for Luke.

When they arrived at Helen's house, Ben told Luke of Katie's satin-balls, which made both mouths water. It soon became a tradition to take Ben to Helen's house to play with Luke. A year would soon come since Ben was adopted, a celebration which entailed copious treats and nearly-unlimited food.

Then, one day, as Luke groped with his foot for the stair underneath him, he took an longer time than he usually did; and his knee buckled, causing the wind to be knocked out of him. He finally managed to climb the stairs breathless.

Luke never seemed to realize the connection between his weight and his ailments, so he turned to food for comfort. This culminated one day when Luke couldn't heave his body up the stairs to his house. No matter what he tried, he couldn't push his weight with two legs up the stairs. Eventually, Helen took pity and helped him up the stairs.

Ben watched as Helen helped Luke up the three stairs to her kitchen. Sam raised his eyebrows inquisitively at the dog too big to walk up the stairs. "Helen, do you ever wonder whether Luke is a bit too… big?" Sam questioned. Helen looked puzzled at his question before she responded, "I'm afraid he has doggy-arthritis. It hurts his joints to move around a lot." Sam was unconvinced if the order of thise two events, but accepted her word.

Luke was stuck. He wanted to stand, but found that his legs wouldn't support him for more than a few steps before they gave out. Helen had called Luke from the kitchen, Luke had barely made his way acroos the room. Luke started whining and barking because he couldn't get up. Helen had dealt with dogs who couldn't walk before, even big ones. She got a towel and threaded it aptly underneath Luke, who now had his pride thoroughly wounded. In a concerted effort, Luke managed to stay on his feet all the way to the kitchen. As he walked, Luke noticed that his joints didn't hurt as badly when he had Helen's support. Then, a thought that he would never be able to shake crept into his mind: his weight was causing his maladies. Luke chuckled at the thought and dismissed it. He just needed to acclimate his body.

After his nap, Luke tried to stand again. He ignored the burning in his knees and kept standing. Finally, when his muscles felt numb, his body actually collapsed, which surprised and knocked the wind out of Luke, who lay panting, exhausted for a few minutes before he tried again. Although it was imperceptible to Luke, he managed to stay standing for a little longer each time he stood.

Ben awoke with a snort, panting for breath. He felt like he had been choking before he was snapped awake. He tried to go back to sleep, but experienced the same problem just after dawn. Ben panicked; what was causing this. Ben had no idea what sleep apnea was or how obesity exacerbated this condition, but he knew it wasn't normal.

Ben awoke with a start, gasping for breath. Sam, who was sitting next to Ben, snapped at the gasping next to him. It had come from Ben, of that he was sure. He called Katie in, "Dear, I think something's wrong with Ben." Katie looked incredulous, "Look, Sam, if this is about Ben's weight, the Vet said that he's healthy; so let it be, Sam." Sam scowled and lowered his voice, "Tell me, Katie, is waking up from your sleep gasping normal?"

Katie pondered this for a moment, "Sam, you're overreacting. He probably just sneezed or something." Sam resigned and accepted Katie's argument. He had heard Ben sneeze before, and that sound was nothing like a sneeze but choking. Meanwhile, he looked up a dog's ideal-weight chart and compared the standard to Ben, who looked nothing like any of the pictures. He scrolled to a more detailed chart and read the description.

11132.content:
Tommy, the little Irish Setter puppy, was staring in the pond in the garden of the house where he lived. He had a comfortable life, all four months of it, but that wasn't on his mind. What was on his mind, was his reflection.

He was a typical Irish Setter pup. He was a little over 10 inches tall, with a square muzzle, soulful brown eyes, and thin floppy ears. He was coated with short, auburn fur, and a thick tail. But his most distinctive feature was his tummy. Tommy had always been the chubby one of the five in the litter, and even when he was born he had a rotund belly. His owners adored all of their puppies, but Tommy seemed, to him, to be their favourite. They loved to stroke and pet his cute flab, as he spent long hours curled up on a sofa, or a bed, with one of the humans who looked after him and his family.

Now it was no different. A normal Irish Setter pup of his age, should weigh about 18-20lbs, but Tommy tipped the scales at two stone in weight. His tummy had stayed the same proportions as when he was tiny, but now he was much bigger, and so was it. He was weaned off his mother's milk recently, and that allowed his owners to fill him with crunchy kibble, wet dog food and occasional table scraps, making sure that he would keep his puppy-fat and pudgy belly.

His red-furred belly jutted out from his flanks about two inches on either side, and it was quite spherical, hanging down beneath him. Tommy lay on his side, to get a better view of himself. The fur on his tummy was actually being separated slightly, so it was thinner, and his pink skin could be seen at close range. He put one of his forepaws to it, feeling his belly. It felt soft, and cushiony beneath him, and moved slightly as he pressed it, his paw sinking in slightly.

Just then, his sister Sarah, walked over to him, looking excited. She was an energetic little puppy, who was beginning to lose her 'puppy-fat', which just speeded her up even more. She looked like an average Irish Setter puppy, except she had longer ears than her brother, and of course, did not have a large belly, but rather a smooth, flat transition from ribs to stomach. Tommy looked his sister's midsection, and felt that her svelte waist was emphasising his podge.

"What're you doing, tummy?" she asked in her chirpy voice. Because of his size, Tommy was frequently given nicknames referring to his roundness. He didn't mind them though, because he knew his belly was giving him extra petting and affection from their owners, but the others weren't jealous.

"Nothing Sarah," replied Tommy. He looked at his sister for a second, scrutinising her comparative wiriness to his round belly. "Sarah?" he asked.

"What, is anything wrong?" she said a little concerned. All of his brothers and sisters were very close.

"Do you, think that this," pointing his muzzle at his belly, "is a little big for a dog my age?"

Sarah was taken aback a little by this, but answered his question.

"Well, I don't think it is," she deduced, "but I'm probably not the right person to ask, you should ask Mummy instead."

"But what do you think?" Tommy persisted.

"I think it makes you look adorable!" replied Sarah, smiling. "Besides," she continued, leaning her head into her brothers tummy, "it makes you so soft and huggable, like a big, furry pillow," and she cuddled up to him, relaxing luxuriously on his belly. She lay there for a few seconds, before she got back up.

"Feel better about it?"

"Yeah, thanks Sarah."

"Tommy?"

"Yes Sarah?" he asked.

Sarah pulled close to him, and pressed a forepaw to his shiny black nose. "You're it!" she whispered, and she ran off giggling.

"Oh no you don't!" Tommy called back playfully, and he got up, and ran after her. He moved quite quickly for a puppy of his rotundness, though his belly did mean that he ran with a gambolling gait. After a few minutes, his other litter mates joined in the game, after hearing the commotion from inside. They were all built along the same lines of Sarah, but all had slightly different features.

Alfie, was the smallest, youngest one, with short fur, and deep green eyes, and looked more like Tommy than the others, as he was slightly chubby, with a little belly, too. But he was nowhere near as husky as Tommy. He was also sprightly, but liked to spend long hours relaxing with his owners, curled up on the sofa with Tommy, and 'their' humans.

Dora was a mirror of Sarah, looking almost identical, and was just as playful and energetic. The only real ways to differ between the two, was that Dora had slightly longer fur on her belly, which she inherited from her dad, and was a little bit thinner than the other puppies, her waist curving up slightly, a trim and perky little pup.

Matt was the oldest of them, and was slightly bigger then all the others, by perhaps one paw width. He was also the most mature of them, but that was easy to be considering they were all still young, and he loved to play with his siblings and run around with them, but he was not always on the go, like his sisters were. He had light brown eyes, a slight belly like Alfie, and had slightly lighter fur on his paws than his litter mates.

They all loved each other, and their parents dearly, who loved them back just as much.

They played tag for a while, and Tommy was usually it, due to his belly impeding his movement slightly, slowing him down, but he was till able to catch the others.

111321.content:
Looking out with deep brown eyes, through the thin, clear panes of the sliding door was a much larger Irish Setter, the puppies' mother Lulu. At twenty seven inches in height, she was quite large for her breed, and not only in that respect. While she was pregnant with her litter, her owners and her mate had encouraged eating much larger portions at mealtimes, to allow for the extra energy required for the growth and nurture of Lulu's puppies. Rex, the father of the puppies, had also been very protective of her, rarely allowing her to overstretch herself, for he cared deeply for his mate, and would spend hours at a time by her side.

However, the increased consumption and lack of mobility had left a definite mark on her frame. During the short eight weeks, she had put on a fair amount of pudge which seemed to collect mainly around her tummy, meaning that she still looked pregnant for several weeks after giving birth. Her auburn bellyfur stretched by her expanded tummy and the rest of her body inflated to a smaller, but still noticable degree. In the weeks that followed, she was still allowed to free-feed by the family, and her waist contiued to expand with softness, as she and Rex looked after their young. She was an intensively motherly dog, always looking out for and fretting over her little ones.

But after the puppies were weened off her milk, Lulu began to lose some of the weight she had gained. More activity in her life had allowed her stomach to shrink as the setter's fat melted slowly off her, but soonLulu was starting to slow down again. She had no real reason to lose the weight, and she was excercised by her owners at least daily, so she would have nothing to worry about from being a little heavy set.

Lulu sighed a little, still gazing at her offspring, and lay down on the plush carpet. She was glad that she had children, and loved them to bits, but they could be oh-so tiring, particulrly the twosome of Dora and Sarah. While they were outside, she could catch up on some rest, and the Setter closed her eyes in preparation for a good nap.

Just then, the door was brushed open, and the sound of heavy breathing entered the room. Lulu turner her head, still lying down, to look at the intruder. It was Rex, and her expression immediately softened. He was a lean and wiry dog, unlike his mate, but he couldn't care about her physical condition, he loved her too much to be swayed by such things. Twenty eight inches high, with strong legs and seemingly straggly fur, his appearance suggested a rough character, but Rex had a heart of gold. Caring madly for his mate and children, he was the first to suggest to her that she take it easy in her delicate state. Now, half of his day would be spent frollicking with his children, a playful soul.

Rex glided softly into the room, and lay down next to Lulu, leaning gently against her. He could feel her rounded stomach against his skinny waist. He cocked his head towards hers.

"'See you still have some holiday weight," he said playfully.

"I know dear, but you don't mind do you?" she asked.

"Why would I mind? I'd love you however big you were," he replied, pushing lightly against her luxuriously soft side. "What were you staring at?" he inquired.

"Oh, nothing, I was just watching the kids. I can't believe how much they've grown already. I can still see them no bigger than your muzzle, and now look at them."

"I can't believe it either."

"There's something worrying me though," said Lulu, her words sounding a little shaky.

"What is it, is it something serious?" replied Rex.

"Not really. But, don't you think some of them are getting bigger in a different way. Look at Tommy," she said, staring at her son.

Rex did the same, and knew what she meant instantly from the way he was lolloping around, trying to keep up with his siblings. Tommy was chubby to say the least, bordering on downright fat. Rex stared intently at his child, the way his round tummy was moving, but also saw Tommy laughing, having fun and enjoying himself. Rex knew that his owners were overfeeding his son, but he saw no malice in them when they did, or when they rubbed his engorged stomach after a meal, stroking the puppy. He remembered how they treated his mate when she was growing rounder almost by the day, and how they made sure she was as safe as could be. He then looked at Lulu, her present, slightly heavy form a tribute to her indulgence. He smiled, and responded gently to her question.

"Honey, I don't know why you're worrying. Sure, Tommy's a little heavy, but so are Alfie and Matt, and they don't have any problems. You know that our owners would never do anything to hurt us or the pups," he said, nuzzling her softly afterwards.

"You're right, the puppies are fine, I should know that. Michael and Sally (The Mother and Father in the family that owns them) care so much about us, I don't know what I was thinking, thank you dear," and she licked the tip of his muzzle.

The two proud parents continued to watch their children play, but Rex soon remembered why he came into the room in the first place. His eyes opened wide, and his breathing sharpened up. Lulu noticed almost immediately.

"Rex, what's the matter?" she inquired, panicing.

"I overheard Micheal and Sally earlier. They were talking about..." he stopped for a few seconds, shivering, " The Vet!" he whispered to Lulu, almost distraught. He was petrified of that place, and was verging on needing sedatives last time he was taken there.

"Shh, calm down," said his mate softly, "I'm sure it's just a check up." She nuzzled hi to try and relax her partner, but he wasn't swayed.

"No, I know what it'll be. They're going to get me fixed! Just one more night..." he was seriously fretting now, but Lulu intervened.

"But what bad will it do? You already have five wonderful children and I love you more than the Earth and always will do."

"But, you know. There's one thing that we'll never be able to do again after then," he responded. The penny dropped for Lulu, and she smirked slightly.

"Well, if we only have one more night..." she started, and left the sentence hanging, wriggling her hips slightly. Rex cottoned on.

"You mean.."

"Yes"

"...Tonight?"

"After the puppies are all in the land of nod, we go outside, and 'do our thing'," she replied, rubbing her mate's side. His mood quickly changed.

"Oh thank you thank you thank you!" he jabbered. "I love you so much, and I want you to know it!"

"I already do, loverboy," she replied, "but not a word about this until the pups are asleep," she finished smiling.

"I understand love."

"I just know it's going to be a checkup, but since you insist.." and the pair left the room to round up their children for dinner before the sun started to set.
